[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/RougeoleDP.jpg/250px-RougeoleDP.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:RougeoleDP.jpg) Measles rash shown on child. The rash typically appears after four days

In the United States, before the measles vaccination program started in 1963, the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention "Centers for Disease Control and Prevention") (CDC) estimated that about three to four million people were infected each year, of which approximately 500,000 were reported, with 400 to 500 people dying and 48,000 being hospitalized.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-cdc-3) Measles is one of the most contagious viruses, and can be passed through respiratory droplets in the air, with unvaccinated individuals at 90% risk of getting measles if they are exposed.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-:1-4) Symptoms usually develop 10–12 days after exposure to an infected person and last 7–10 days.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-WHO2014-5)[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-Conn2014-6) Initial symptoms typically include [fever](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fever "Fever"), often greater than 40 °C (104 °F), cough, [runny nose](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhinitis "Rhinitis"), and [inflamed eyes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conjunctivitis "Conjunctivitis"), with a red, flat rash which usually starts on the face and then spreads to the rest of the body.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-CDC2014SS2-7)[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-MM2014-8)

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Measles_US_1938-2019.png/250px-Measles_US_1938-2019.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Measles_US_1938-2019.png) Graph showing the numbers of reported cases of measles between 1938-2019

The [MMR vaccine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MMR_vaccine "MMR vaccine") is a safe and effective preventative measure against measles with the first dose given to children between 12 and 15 months of age and a second dose between 4 and 6 years.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-h218-9) Though measles was [eliminated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eradication_of_infectious_disease "Eradication of infectious disease") in the United States in 2000, falling vaccination rates have contributed to [its resurgence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measles_resurgence_in_the_United_States "Measles resurgence in the United States").[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-h218-9) Vaccination rates among children have dropped since the [COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic") and most states have dropped below the 95% threshold considered effective to prevent community outbreaks.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-h218-9)[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-b459-10) Falling vaccination rates have been tied to increased skepticism about vaccines.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-11)

The high rate of vaccination exemptions in Gaines County, Texas, has been blamed for the outbreak.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-12) It has one of the highest rates in the country of vaccine opt-outs among children, with nearly 14% skipping a required vaccine in the prior school year.[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-p800-13) The outbreak has been concentrated in a [Mennonite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mennonites#Organization:_North_America "Mennonites") community known to be under-vaccinated.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-h218-9)

## Epidemiology

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Epidemiology")\]

The initial outbreak of measles which had previously been eradicated in North America, originated from unvaccinated people in [Ontario](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontario "Ontario"), [Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada "Canada") before spreading to the Southwest US, which later spread to the [Midwest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midwest "Midwest"). The disease has infected mostly unvaccinated [Mennonite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mennonite "Mennonite") communities.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-14)[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-15)

As of March 7, 2025, 228 cases have been confirmed.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-CNN230Cases-16) In mid-February, it was reported that of the reported cases 39 were aged between 0–4 years old, 62 were aged 5–17 years old, 18 were aged 18 and older, with five cases not completely age identified.[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-:1-4) Since there have been two deaths and the fatality rate of measles is estimated to be around one to three deaths per 1000, epidemiologists suspect the number of cases could be much higher.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-u571-17) The outbreak came amid sporadic smaller outbreaks across the United States.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-i901-18) The majority of cases have been in children who are unvaccinated or of unknown vaccination status, with a hospitalization rate of 17%; the origin of the outbreak is unknown.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-i901-18)

### Texas

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Texas")\]

On January 17, 2025, the [Houston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Houston "Houston") Health Department confirmed two cases of [measles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measles "Measles"), the first reported cases in Houston since 2018. The patients were in the same household and had traveled recently.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-19) Two cases in unvaccinated school-age children in [Lubbock, Texas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lubbock,_Texas "Lubbock, Texas"), were later confirmed; the last case of measles in [Lubbock County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lubbock_County,_Texas "Lubbock County, Texas") was reported in 2004.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-20) The first child in Lubbock had contracted the disease after sitting in an emergency room with another child who was sick.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-h218-9) The children resided in [Gaines County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaines_County,_Texas "Gaines County, Texas").[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-21) By February 7, the number of confirmed cases had increased to nine with three probable cases,[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-22) before reaching fourteen confirmed cases with six probable cases.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-23)

By mid February it was reported that the outbreak had spread to nine Texas counties mostly concentrated in the rural [South Plains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Plains "South Plains") region, with counties including [Dallam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dallam_County,_Texas "Dallam County, Texas"), [Dawson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawson_County,_Texas "Dawson County, Texas"), [Ector](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ector_County,_Texas "Ector County, Texas"), [Gaines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaines_County,_Texas "Gaines County, Texas"), [Lubbock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lubbock_County,_Texas "Lubbock County, Texas"), [Lynn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lynn_County,_Texas "Lynn County, Texas"), [Terry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terry_County,_Texas "Terry County, Texas"), and [Yoakum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoakum_County,_Texas "Yoakum County, Texas").[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-:1-4) It was reported on February 24, that a person with measles had traveled outside of the outbreak area, to visit the campus of [University of Texas at San Antonio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Texas_at_San_Antonio "University of Texas at San Antonio") and other local establishments.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-:0-24) By late February more than 20 patients have been hospitalized at [Covenant Children's Hospital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Covenant_Children%27s_Hospital "Covenant Children's Hospital"). Some of them were suffering [bacterial pneumonia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bacterial_pneumonia "Bacterial pneumonia") and were requiring [intubation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tracheal_intubation "Tracheal intubation") to breathe.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-h218-9)

On February 26, an unvaccinated six-year-old girl died of measles in Lubbock, the first death attributed to the outbreak.[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-NYTimesFirstDeath-25)[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-s916-26) She had been sick for three weeks before being put on a ventilator and succumbing to pneumonia.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-s916-26) She was the first measles death in the country since 2015.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-v377-27) In a media interview less than a month later, the girl's father commented that "vaccination has stuff we don't trust … We don't like the vaccinations, what they have these days. We heard too much, and we saw too much."[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-s916-26) Also in the same time period, the girl's father and mother, who are [Mennonites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mennonites "Mennonites"), both appeared on video for a video interview by anti-vaccine organisation [Children's Health Defense](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Children%27s_Health_Defense "Children's Health Defense"), where the father said that "measles are good for the body", while the mother told other parents regarding the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine: "Don't do the shots", with measles being "not as bad as they’re making it out to be."[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-28)

[Austin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austin,_Texas "Austin, Texas") confirmed on February 28 its first measles case since 2019, an unvaccinated infant who contracted the disease while overseas.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-i939-29)

On April 3, an eight-year-old girl died of "measles pulmonary failure" in Lubbock, marking the second child death from the outbreak.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-s236-30) She was not vaccinated.[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-b039-31)

Texas declared their outbreak over as of August 18th, 2025 after a total of 762 reported cases.[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-32)

### New Mexico

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: New Mexico")\]

[New Mexico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico") health officials began checking residents for measles on February 3.[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-33) On March 6, an unvaccinated adult in [Lea County](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lea_County,_New_Mexico "Lea County, New Mexico") died and was later revealed to have contracted measles prior to his death.[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-34)

### Oklahoma

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Oklahoma")\]

The first two cases linked to the outbreak were identified in Oklahoma on March 11.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-o569-35)

### Kansas

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Kansas")\]

By March 28, 23 cases had been confirmed in Kansas; 21 of the cases were in children, and 20 of the total cases were in unvaccinated individuals.[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-y806-36) Genetic analyses suggest they were related to the Texas outbreak, but the exact exposure is not known.[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-y806-36)

### Chihuahua

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Chihuahua")\]

The Mexican state of [Chihuahua](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chihuahua_(state) "Chihuahua (state)"), where the vaccination rate is at 75%, identified 15 cases of measles in [Cuauhtémoc](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuauht%C3%A9moc,_Chihuahua "Cuauhtémoc, Chihuahua") and one in [Namiquipa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Namiquipa "Namiquipa") on March 12.[\[37\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-a050-37) The outbreak has been concentrated in a Mennonite community whose members regularly travel to Texas to visit family and carry out business.[\[38\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-l571-38) There were also 25 cases of [whooping cough](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whooping_cough "Whooping cough") (pertussis) discovered.[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-c549-39)

## Responses

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Responses")\]

### Federal

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Federal")\]

During a [cabinet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_cabinet_of_Donald_Trump "Second cabinet of Donald Trump") meeting on February 26, [Robert F. Kennedy Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Jr. "Robert F. Kennedy Jr."), the [United States secretary of health and human services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Health_and_Human_Services "United States Secretary of Health and Human Services") (HHS), stated: "We are following the measles epidemic every day. Incidentally, there have been four measles outbreaks this year. In this country last year there were 16. So, it's not unusual. We have measles outbreaks every year."[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-nbc20250226-40) Kennedy, who is known for his [anti-vaccine activism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-vaccine_activism "Anti-vaccine activism") and history of downplaying measles resurgences, also stated incorrectly that there were two deaths and that the hospitalizations were for quarantine purposes.[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-NYTimesFirstDeath-25)[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-n004-41) Only one death had been recorded at that time,[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-v377-27) and officials in Lubbock stated that they do not hospitalize patients for quarantine purposes. The officials stated that the children who were admitted were having difficulty breathing (with some requiring [intensive care](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intensive_care "Intensive care") and supplemental oxygen). They added that all of the admitted children were unvaccinated.[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-nbc20250226-40) Senator [Bill Cassidy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Cassidy "Bill Cassidy"), who chaired the Senate health committee, tweeted that the death was "absolutely devastating" and encouraged parents to vaccinate their children.[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-h748-42)[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-43)

Infectious disease experts Cameron Wolfe of [Duke University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duke_University "Duke University"), David Higgins of the [University of Colorado](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Colorado "University of Colorado"), and former head of the National Immunization Program [Walter Orenstein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_Orenstein "Walter Orenstein") objected to Kennedy's description of the outbreak as "not unusual" and stated the child's death was fully preventable with proper vaccination.[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-NYTimesFirstDeath-25)[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-v377-27) [Ali S. Khan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ali_S._Khan "Ali S. Khan"), the former Director of the Office of Public Health Preparedness and Response at the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention "Centers for Disease Control and Prevention") (CDC) called for political officials at all levels to promote vaccination.[\[44\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-y527-44) In contrast to the [2019 New York measles outbreak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_New_York_measles_outbreak "2019 New York measles outbreak")—when CDC officials and Health Secretary [Alex Azar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Azar "Alex Azar") urged vaccination—the CDC and Health Secretary did not release statements or make posts on social media urging vaccination.[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-h748-42) On March 4, the CDC, which had been providing MMR vaccines and lab support, posted on X that the [Epidemic Intelligence Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic_Intelligence_Service "Epidemic Intelligence Service") would be helping the Texas State Department of Health.[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-x264-45) The organization also began planning a large-scale study of [vaccines and autism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccines_and_autism "Vaccines and autism"), though extensive research has shown no connection between the two.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-y522-46)

Kennedy published an opinion piece about the outbreak on the [Fox News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_News "Fox News") website on March 2.[\[47\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-j596-47) He suggested parents consult with healthcare providers about vaccination, but did not explicitly recommend it, stating the choice was "personal."[\[48\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-z502-48)[\[49\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-c731-49) He also promoted [vitamin A](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vitamin_A "Vitamin A") supplementation and, in later interviews, [cod liver oil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cod_liver_oil "Cod liver oil"), neither of which are effective treatments.[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-a107-50) Infectious disease specialists interviewed by [Stat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stat_(website) "Stat (website)") interpreted Kennedy's column as echoing the messages of [anti-vaccine activists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-vaccine_activists "Anti-vaccine activists"), who emphasize nutrition, supplementation, and parental choice over vaccination.[\[51\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-d527-51) Kennedy gave an interview to Fox News' [Marc Siegel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc_Siegel "Marc Siegel") on March 8 in which he made numerous false claims including that it is "almost impossible" for healthy individuals to die from infectious disease and that the child who died may have been [malnourished](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malnourished "Malnourished"), despite health official's statements that she had no underlying conditions.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-s916-26)[\[52\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-s097-52) Kennedy's promotion of unproven treatments for measles during the outbreak was cited as one of the reasons for the resignation of Kevin Griffis, the CDC communications director.[\[53\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-e081-53)[\[54\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-f089-54)

In April, federal budget cuts led to layoffs of frontline workers and the cancellation of over 50 measles vaccination clinics in Texas, many of which were planned in areas with low vaccination rates.[\[55\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-k843-55)[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-o914-56) After a second child died of measles, Kennedy attended her funeral.[\[57\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-e430-57) He met with the families of both children who died of measles, stated that the CDC would redeploy a team to Texas at the request of governor [Greg Abbott](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Abbott "Greg Abbott"), and that HHS would follow the state's lead.[\[58\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-t335-58)

Afterwards Kennedy posted on X that "the most effective way to prevent the spread of measles is the MMR vaccine" but again did not explicitly recommend it.[\[58\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-t335-58) He also praised two doctors (Ben Edwards and Richard Barlett) who had treated children with aerosolized [budesonide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Budesonide "Budesonide") (a [steroid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steroid "Steroid")) and [clarithromycin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clarithromycin "Clarithromycin") (an antibiotic)—which may weaken the immune system—as "extraordinary healers".[\[58\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-t335-58) Edwards had earlier in the outbreak described mass infections as "God's version of measles immunization",[\[59\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-k273-59) and Barlett had inaccurately promoted budesonide as a cure for [COVID-19](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19 "COVID-19")[\[59\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-k273-59) and been disciplined in 2003 by the Texas Medical Board for "unusual use of risk-filled medications".[\[60\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-n398-60)[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-s328-61)

### State and local

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: State and local")\]

Schools did not order unvaccinated students to stay home as it would require declaring a [state of emergency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_of_emergency "State of emergency").[\[62\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-i193-62) The Texas Department of State Health Services stated that such a declaration was not necessary since 90% of Texans are vaccinated; they ordered a 21-day quarantine for exposed unvaccinated individuals, but this would not be tracked or enforced.[\[62\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-i193-62) In rural Texas, the challenges of the outbreak were exacerbated by a lack of adequate public health infrastructure, primary care practitioners, and funding as 26 hospitals had closed between 2010 and 2020.[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-t517-63)

As news of the outbreak spread, health officials reported a rise in families deciding to vaccinate their children. The director of public health in Lubbock county stated that in the last week of February 2025 they had given approximately 100 doses of the MMR vaccine to children who had previously been unvaccinated or whose parents did not believe in vaccines.[\[64\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-b011-64) Vaccine-hesitant parents, including those who had sought exemptions for their children, were also bringing them to receive vaccines.[\[65\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-h078-65) High demand for vaccines caused shortages in some parts of Texas, particularly Austin.[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Southwest_United_States_measles_outbreak#cite_note-a107-50) State vaccine registry
